text:
On twitter, After Ellen said that women have the right to refuse sex to whoever they want for whatever reason. What was Riley's response? "even if that reason is "you're disgusting and vile because you're trans and i think you'd be better off dead" lol bye after ellen"
Uhh, Riles, does that mean that a woman doesn not have the right to turn down a transman/woman down for sex? Gee. Riles... that... that sounds a bit rapey to me. Don't you think?

author: @oteulisagyndyk916
text: Funny how you never call Riley "he"or "she" and instead uses "Riley" or "R.J".

author: @Selrisitai
text:
I notice that the word _discriminatory_ doesn't really have a definition to some people. It's not really used like a normal word, with a logical, defined meaning that is being referenced; rather, it's used _emotionally._ The word _discriminatory_ immediately makes people feel icky because it's been associated with negative things, specifically morally dubious discrimination. 

When he says, "That's pretty discriminatory" if I don't date a transsexual person, he's actually correct in the words he's using: I discriminate in my dating preferences. I only date chicks, and I don't date obese chicks, for instance, or I don't date at all since I'm already dating a chick. I'm "discriminating" or, to use the more "nice" word, though one with an admittedly different denotation (and connotation), I'm _discerning._  

I don't date people with penises, even if that penis has been mutilated or never grew in properly. That is me discriminating. 

What this person _means_ to say is, "That's mean," and on that we disagree.
